social_posts.post_text: 🍯♨️🍯♨️🍯 With the holiday rush shelf space is maxed out but there’s always more space with a little creativity. My rafters are the perfect drying rack with heat rising up for quicker and more even drying!
🔥🍯🥶🍯🔥 #AdamFieldOnggi

I just unloaded fifteen 1-gallon ($125 + $25 S&H) and fifteen 2-gallon ($180 + $30 S&H) Onggi jars from the kiln! I’ve set December 15th as my last day for shipping in time for pre-Christmas arrival. Message me for yours today and while they last, they go quick this time of year.

🎄👶🏻🤰🏼❤️ Jesse and I are excitedly preparing for the arrival of our new baby boy after a long IVF journey.

🔥🍶🔥🍶🔥 Moon (@moondobang) is coming to the US for a workshop tour which will include a 2-day intensive hands-on workshop with me here at Adam Field Pottery! I am so thrilled to see my good friend after so many years. Space is limited to just 8 participants, details coming soon!
🔥🍶🔥 ENROLLMENT OPEN!! Link in profile! *UPDATE*: This workshop has filled.

🥬🍯🌶 Kimchi party in Seattle with an #AdamFieldOnggi! I really love receiving images of my Onggi being used for what they were made to do. This lovely gathering shows how kimchi making can be a community bonding gathering and I’m all about it! 
•
This serves as the LAST CALL for pre-holiday Onggi orders. I have 1 & 2-gallon Onggi fermentation jars on hand and ready to ship out. Message me to order yours and to set in motion a future kimchi party of your own!

🌱🍯🌱 Loving this image from Lexie Park of @eatnunchi. Lexie received this custom inscribed #AdamFieldOnggi as an early Christmas present earlier today. If you aren’t already following Lexie you’ll want to take a look at @eatnunchi to see great food content, beautiful photos, and some of the most creative and beautiful cakes I have ever seen. Thank you Lexie for making my Onggi look so good. 🌱🍯🌱
•
ps, the inscription says Nunchi in Korean Hangul.
•

Reposting from @flmceramics:
“It’s rare that you get to present what you do in tandem with one of your closest friends, someone who you’ve shared parallel careers and experiences with in your field, but here we are. I’m so excited to invite @adamfieldpottery to co-teach a workshop at our studio @petalumapottery in Petaluma, California! This workshop will be a part of a larger collaborative effort between the two of us on a new line of tile, and custom project for a client where Adam and I will be working in tandem at #FLMCERAMICS the week before, and the week after the Saturday workshop, and during the workshop, we will do a studio tour and will break down the ins and outs of working collaboratively. We hope you’ll join us Saturday, Jan 21st and share in this exciting opportunity! Workshop/demonstration is limited to 40 participants.”

❤️🍯❤️ The calm after the chaos of the annual holiday rush is made so much sweeter as the images of my creations in their new homes make their way back to me. An opportunity to see some of the joy and connectivity they will bring. This is a big part of why I chose the path of handmade pottery. Happy holidays to you and to those you love and who love you. 
•
I received these heartwarming images from my good friend and one of my favorite potters, Doug Peltzman (@dougpeltzman) who has plans for a big (3-gallon) batch of miso in the near future!
❤️🍯❤️

🍯🍯🍯 2-WEEK Onggi intensive workshop!! Excited to announce my first ever 2-week Onggi intensive where we will be making Onggi together from start to finished and fired pots. If that wasn’t enough it will all take place at @andersonranchartscenter in beautiful Snowmass Village, Colorado.
•
Korean Onggi: Coil, Paddle, Form, Ferment • (July 24 - Aug. 4)
“Adam Field will share the traditional Korean Onggi coil and paddle pottery techniques he learned during his Onggi apprenticeship with Onggi Master Kim Ill Maan. Participants will learn and practice all steps of this ancient process including rolling and paddling large coils, wheel throwing and forming traditional Onggi vessels, glazing, firing, and even fermenting with guest fermentation professionals. Participants gain a historical perspective through the creation of the oldest continuously practiced pottery tradition. Generous discussions about aesthetics, materials, ceramic history, and studio workflow are certain to encourage individual discovery, growth, and development of fresh ideas. Participants gain skills, knowledge, and confidence to create and decorate historically informed functional pots in their own voice.”
•
Link in profile, enrollment opens January 4th!

🌊🍯🌊🍯🌊 Always exciting to see the install! This one at the amazing new Korean Cultural Center building in NYC! You may remember this group of Onggi from posts a few months back. More images to come as the project nears completion.

❄️🍽❄️🥣❄️🍵❄️ Fresh porcelain with ice blue celadon on the subzero Montana morning.

❄️🥶❄️ This is what happens to boiling water when it’s -35°F outside! I would have made my own video but it’s too damn cold out. Stay warm, stay safe. 
•
Wonderful video by @amma_5

🔪🤖✂️🍯 Diving in deep, failing, learning, and having some success. New tools always have a good way of mixing things up a bit in the studio and reassessing my approach. This will save me a lot of time which will open up time for more exploration. Feeling excited over here!
❤️👶🏻❤️ We checked in on our little guy this morning! Jesse (@wildwillowwellness) and I are beside ourselves. ❤️ #20Weeks

🥩❤️🌯❤️🎃 Love making family batches of burritos for our Montana family road trips, this time it’s ground beef, zucchini, butternut squash, and Monterey Jack. I got hooked on steam melted cheese from my years living right down the street from Gordo’s on Solano Ave. in the East Bay back in the early 2000s. Hot sauce not pictured! 🌶🤤🌯

👉🏼🍶👈🏼 I’ve been making pots for about 25 years, the first four of which I didn’t really have much of a clear idea of what I could do to move and distribute the clay in a way that resulted in walls with even thickness while maximizing height gain. After making thousands of pots and taking a lot of workshops from some very skilled makers the lightbulb finally came on! I start by scooping under that spot at the base of the wall that is hardest to thin. Next my interior hand presses and thins the wall while slightly higher than my outside hand (I always thought that both hands were supposed to be at the same height). The outside hand follows up pressing the clay that had been stretched back into the original plane of the wall transferring the stretched clay into height gained. When I started teaching workshops in 2009 I had a hard time describing this until I realized that the cross section view would make it much more clear and have been starting my workshops with demo ever since. I hope this is helpful, I know I wish I had seen this when I was first getting started making pots. 🍶

✨🍯✨ A look at the Onggi process from a recent project. They usually don’t have a hole in the bottom but the project called for it.

💥🍶🧷 Dots on pots! Laying out for carved porcelain cups today in the studio!

💥🍯💥 JOIN ME AT @andersonranchartscenter for a 2-week Onggi intensive workshop! I came up with this method for practicing the coil attachment part of the Onggi process as it can be quite challenging to attach a coil to the rim of a soft clay pot. The rigid wall of a 5-gallon bucket helps to remove one big pitfall from the steep Onggi learning curve. Learn this and SO MUCH MORE by making, glazing, firing, and fermenting with me in beautiful Aspen, Colorado! Full info linked in my profile!
•
#AdamFieldOnggi

✨🍶✨ It’s been a great visit for a collaboration and workshop with @flmceramics this week. Having arrived on Wednesday Forrest and I got to work in the studio on developing a collaborative line of carved porcelain tile that will be available for purchase through FLM Ceramics this coming spring. Forrest is one of my closest friends and it’s been great to work with him on this project. Our all-day demonstration and workshop this Saturday (tomorrow!) still has room, so if you’d like to join us for an informative and story-filled day of making join us by signing up through the link in my profile, or by visiting Petalumapottery.com (@petalumapottery)

⭐️⭐️⭐️ Jesse and I had our first 3-Michelin star restaurant experience on Friday night in San Francisco. Chef Corey Lee (@clee_benu) and his team at Benu (@benu_sf) did not disappoint! 20 courses with pairing made for a delicious journey of flavors all presented in a most beautiful way. Many of the courses included foods fermented in Chef Lee’s impressive Onggi collection at the entrance courtyard. Thank you Chef Lee for such a special experience.
🐶 Jesse & I had a wonderful visit with Echo this week. It was fun to see her people too 😜.

⭐️🔲⭐️🔲⭐️ Back home after a week in Petaluma, CA for a collaboration tile project with my good friends Forrest Middelton and Beth Schaible (@flmceramics & @quillandarrow)! We have wanted to collaborate to bring my carved pattern into the FLM Ceramics custom tile offering for years and we are excited to be well underway. This clip shows just two of many designs we are working on and some of the mold making process that goes into Rampressing tile. More to come!
•
Special thanks to @stevenbwheeler (image 1) for your big contribution to the project. 🙏🏼

✨🍯✨ ONGGI WORKSHOP! Join me for a 2-week Onggi intensive this summer in Colorado at @andersonranchartscenter for a deep dive into all steps of this ancient process that falls somewhere between wheel throwing and hand building. From fresh clay to firing to fermenting and all steps in between we will cover it all. There are a few spots left for this unique opportunity. Join me in a beautiful part of my home state, let’s make Onggi together! 🍯🔥🍯. Link with full details in profile and @andersonranchartscenter

✨🍶✨ Day 1 of 2 and I've learned so much from Renee LoPresti (@renee_lopresti). Such a wealth of knowledge and a master of intricate layering and detail. These are my first attempts with this process, I’m feeling inspired for what’s to come! 
•
Big thanks to Curt Hammerly (@hammerlyceramics) for hosting this amazing workshop.

✨🍯✨ Another fun week-long Studio Shadow Session! Kat (@meowmeow0808) from LA shadowed me in the studio last week and she absolutely killed it making a 5-gallon Onggi to add to her family Onggi collection. A talented food stylist, Kat brought dedication and attention to process and detail to her time making Onggi alongside me in my Montana studio and it paid off. Great work Kat!

🔪🍯🔪 I keep coming back for that feeling of completion at the end of carving a piece.
It starts out somewhat boring and with each line carved the pattern and activation of surface grows until I find myself not wanting to stop. 
This one is heading to a special place on the east coast and my mind wonders to that space, imagining it finished and in place as a focal point of a great restaurant where it will hold fresh cut flowers and will add to the dining experience.
I have been listening to nature sounds of rain, streams, and tropical forest soundscapes while carving instead of my usual podcasts starting with this piece. It is nice and it really changed the experience and headspace for me while carving. Looking forward to exploring more sounds to work to.

So excited for @moondobang’s upcoming visit! So many of you have requested a virtual option and here it is!

MOON:MOON
ONGGI:FIELD

A special two-hour workshop with MoonDoBang and Adam Field! 

They will be throwing side by side, exploring two iconic historical Korean pottery forms and the specific steps to make them: the Moon Jar thrown in porcelain and the Onggi Jar form thrown in stoneware (not coil & paddle method). Both traditionally Korean in form but we will compare and contrast the throwing styles demonstrated by master potters Adam Field and Moon Byung Sik.
@moondobang 
@adamfieldpottery 

$50 early bird through March 10 / $60 through April 23

hosted by @kalasteindesign 

Translation by @mikisr_ceramics
 
Link in bio: 👉🏼 @kalasteindesign
☀️🍊🌈🍶☀️ Sun is shinin’
🧀🔥🥯 On this episode of #StudioSnackHacks 😂

🔥🍯🔥 This afternoon in the studio I took a break from my work and down for a chat with my studio assistant, Ryan (@liveslow_pottery). While we talked Ryan continued to throw 1-gallon Onggi giving me a chance to reflect on how good he has gotten at throwing production since he arrived 9 months ago. The easiest way to describe it is in thinking about watching him throw a 1-gallon Onggi when he first arrived, I found myself wanting to stop him at so many steps along the way to point out another way. While watching him today there was none of that. Instead I found it very relaxing and enjoyable to see the economy of motion with which he works in combination with sharp attention to detail. It would be an understatement to say that Ryan is doing well as my studio assistant. Ryan will be here for about five more months at which time he will move on to add another layer to his depth of experience and education. In the meantime we have a lot of work to do!
•
If you’ve read this far, thank you. Also, are you interested in assisting here at AF Pottery after Ryan heads out?

🔥🍯🎥🍶🔥 !!VIRTUAL WORKSHOP!! March 24th! Moon and I will be co-teaching this 2 hour deep dive into two classic Korean forms; the moon jar by Moon and I’ll be making an Onggi! LINK IN PROFILE, enroll before March 10th for early bird pricing. 
•
Join us for a very special two-hour zoom workshop with simultaneous demos with Moon Byung Sik (Moon do Bang) and Adam Field, both presenting directly from Adam’s studio in Helena, Montana. They will be throwing on the wheel side by side, exploring two iconic historical Korean pottery forms and the specific steps to make them. Moon will be using porcelain to throw Moon Jars and Adam will be using stoneware to throw (not coil and paddle) Onggi Jars. Similarities and differences of the forms will be discussed with a breakdown of the proportions and their unique centering and throwing methods used to achieve the elegant jar forms.
•
LINK IN PROFILE: @AdamFieldPottery

❤️🍶❤️ The last couple of days with @moondobang have been a dream come true and a long time coming. Moon and I met about 17 years ago in Korea when he was in the early years of creating MoonDoBang Ceramics. We became fast friends and brothers in clay. When I would make it back to Korea for subsequent visits we could visit and eat good food and search out our favorite pots online to share with one another even with our limited shared language. We talked about hopes of one day making pots together in the US and all these years later we have reached this goal while setting more for the future. Maybe fittingly it is hard for me to find the words to describe my connection and friendship we share. 
❤️

❤️🍶❤️ Reposted from • @moondobang 
“Yesterday, we had a virtual workshop by zoom as soon as we arrived in Montana and today, we finished the day one of the hands-on intensive workshop with @adamfieldpottery
I wonder if Adam remember that 15 years ago, we promised to spin the wheel together in the US. 
It is unreal that, after so many years, we are at the wheel throwing side by side. 
I wish i can take package this happiness to take home with me. 😊🙏🏻”
-MoonDoBang
❤️🍶🏔🍶❤️ And that’s a wrap! What a wonderful and deeply memorable weekend workshop with my brother from another mother, @moondobang!

Reposted • @moondobang

It was a happy time in beautiful Helena”

🌴🔁❄️ With snow falling outside my window here in Helena, I am reflecting on the amazing Los Angeles road trip Hana and I took together and returned from two days ago. We set out with plans of pottery workshops teaching with my friend @moondobang, a long list of amazing restaurants to try and chefs to connect with, and open time to spend with new and long-time friends alike. Each day was full from dawn to dusk. Most importantly we made lifelong memories together! ❤️👸🏻❤️👴🏻❤️

🍯🔁🍯 Reposting from @charlesoller, a student from a distance, Charles has shown persistence and an ability to work hard to progress his pottery skills and a willingness to throw cylinders, dissect, reclaim, and throw again. It is this focus on the act of making and not on the final product that will bring growth. Keep up the hard work, Charles! 
•
The original caption in Charles’ own words:
“Wow, I didn’t realize the quality I was missing out on by using the front camera 😅 Lots and lots of cylinders lately, so I figured I’d share one. The challenge here is exact dimensions, smooth outer AND inner walls, 90 degree wall to floor, and even all the way around. This is an exercise given to me by the master potter himself, @adamfieldpottery and it truly is such a wonderful throwing exercise. I won’t stop with these until I can throw them with my eyes closed. It’s funny how a cylinder is the most basic of forms, and yet a perfect cylinder is something that many potters, including myself if not for Adam, would skip right past in favor of forms that are initially more exciting.”

❤️🍯❤️🐝❤️ A wonderful mail day! As a proud hapa papa I was thrilled to (virtually) meet Laurie and her family who are behind the amazing @hapahoneyfarm. Their award winning organic honey is everything I had imagined it would be and more!💛 
•

✌🏼🍯✌🏼 20-gallon Onggi. Start to finish with an overnight break in between. I always build it up in my head to be such a big task but once I lay down that first coil I drop into the flow and stick to the script and it becomes fun over fear. Good life lessons in this clay path I wandered down all those years back.

✨🌌🍶🌠✨ When I first started making and selling pottery 26 years ago in a time before most pots were bought after being held in the customer’s hands. A customer could feel the weight of a pot and the fit of that pot as they held it. They could inspect all the nooks and crannies and details that don’t easily translate to an image on a computer or smartphone screen. Over time the hands-on selection process shifted to one from a distance which expanded the audience but limited that initial experience before purchasing. I can be slow to change my ways and the transition to sales from a distance was no exception. In thinking about what would be gained my thoughts also went to what could be lost. As someone who not only makes and sells handmade pottery but as a collector I was able to view this shift through that lens as well. In the worst case I would purchase online and receive a piece that didn’t meet my expectations. The realization for me was that I never wanted my pots sold online to not meet the expectations of the person purchasing my work. This prompted me to explore ways in which I could exceed expectations allowing my work to speak in unexpected ways through use. Light passing through translucent porcelain, small stained glass windows in the wall of a cup, intricate decoration revealed with the final sip of a favorite drink. I want my customers to feel that they have received more than they had expected in a world where we are so often being sold less than we bargained for.

🔥🍶🔥 Celadon glazed and fired to cone 10.5 in a reduction atmosphere.

🍯❤️🍯 Making lids for 5-gallon Onggi in the studio today. This process is truly a mix of what I learned during my Korean Onggi apprenticeship and the wheel throwing methods I learned making pots here in the US. My sole focus during my apprenticeship was to make the largest of the Onggi in production in the studio, 150 liters with only one year to do so I had little time for anything else. As a result I didn’t get much practice making Onggi lids. When I returned home to the US and started taking orders of larger Onggi I had to dig deep and combine techniques to make these challenging forms. The combination has worked well and has allowed me to make large Onggi lids without a huge amount of effort. I hope you enjoy the video!
❤️

👶🏻❤️🌱 We are so thrilled to have welcomed Devon Hugo Field into the world at 8:15 am on June 1st! At 10 pounds 6 ounces some of the nurses said he was more of a toddler than a newborn 😂. Both Jesse and Devon are healthy and happy and we are all on cloud 9 ☁️🥰☁️. His middle name was one that we chose in honor of Jesse’s paternal grandfather and was chosen months ago but his first name seemed to require us meeting him face to face. While Jesse and I were on our first drive with Devon through the beautiful and very lush Montana landscape (after all these amazing spring showers) I was reminded of my time in Devon, England where both Jesse and I have separately spent time and of which we both have special memories. 
I am in awe of my powerful wife for all that she has done leading up to Devon’s arrival. I love you, sweet Jesse, thank you is not enough. 
👶🏻❤️🌱

💦💙🍶💙💦 Throwing 2-part sectional porcelain jars in the studio today. I use food coloring to help to keep track of the joint between the two sections. When the piece has had a chance to dry a bit I’ll add a raised coil to the joint as a decorative element before I carve geometric pattern into the surface of the jar. As hard as I try it’s nearly impossible to end up without a bump on the profile of a finished sectional pot where the two sections are attached so years ago I decided to go with it. If you can’t beat’em, join’em! The food coloring burns out in the first firing leaving no trace.

I feel fortunate to have had so many generous teachers and mentors along my path in clay and I feel compelled to offer opportunities to those who are earlier on their paths. Frank and Charles have been throwing very specific practice cylinders and cutting them in half to check wall thickness. It’s not the most fun task but it yields serious rewards in terms of techniques learned for moving clay with skill and intention. I think they have both experienced unexpected growth in their clay work while appreciating the beautiful surroundings that Helena has to offer.

🏔️🍯🔥🌶️🥬 What a special day of pottery workshop kimchi making yesterday here at @andersonranchartscenter just outside of Aspen, CO! My workshop and amazing ceramics studio coordinator Joanne Lee (@swjlceramics) lead the charge and gathered all the key ingredients that her mother’s special recipe called for. Bringing kimchi making into the workshop setting brought the function of the Onggi jars we are making into focus and was a wonderful community connecting ritual that brought visitors to the clay studio from all around campus. My Onggi jars are currently bubbling away with the most amazing kimchi. THANK YOU Joanne and to everyone who lent a helping hand in making it happen, like you said, your mom will be proud!

🍯🔥🍯 My most recent studio assistant, Ryan Greene (@liveslow_pottery), hit the road south to Arizona yesterday. After 14 months here at AFP the time came for him to move on to the next chapter. Ryan will start his time as a graduate candidate in the Arizona State University Ceramics department and I couldn’t be more thrilled for him. Ryan arrived here on June 5th of last year with solid foundational skills and a strong will to learn what it takes to make quality Onggi while jumping in on all necessary tasks that come with running a production pottery studio. Sometimes these tasks included those well outside of the pottery realm while still contributing to the greater success of the business and Ryan always kept a positive attitude and a smile on his face. It has been a true joy to watch Ryan’s growth in the wheel and I can’t wait to see what will come from his time in grad school, great things no doubt! 
Good job, Chef!

❤️hi

❤️🌺❤️ In the depths of the hardest Montana winter in recent memory my wife and her mother braved the cold on a mission to sow some special seeds. You should also know that my wife Jesse (@wildwillowwellness) makes it a point to spend part of if not all of most Augusts in her her home state of Minnesota and neighboring Wisconsin where she often spends a good part of her trip helping out on her friend’s farm in Bayfield, WI. It was on this farm that Jesse was repeatedly impressed by a beautiful variety of poppy. While harvesting some of these poppies for her hosts she was given some seeds to take back home to plant. After a few years of failed attempts she learned that it may be helpful to plant the seeds before winter had subsided. This spring Jesse’s hard work and determination were rewarded with the hundreds of tiny sprouts that marked the start of spring. With plentiful precipitation the sprouts flourished and burst into bloom decorating our raised garden beds with some of the most beautiful poppies I have seen. I have grown to love my daily check in with the poppy beds especially when calming our son, Devon with a walk outside when he gets fussy. As the flower petals have fallen away and the seed pods have dried the cycle continues with the seed harvest and a reminder on the calendar for February sowing of seeds. Thankful to Jesse for bringing such beauty into our lives and into our home. ❤️
•
PS, I think it’s clear that some of my favorite historical pots were heavily influenced by poppy seed pods, the last shot of this clip reminds me of a row of pots freshly unloaded from the kiln. 🍶🍶🍶

❤️❤️❤️Hello family and friends, 
We are reaching out for support for my son Juno after an electrical fire in his downtown Helena apartment in the Iron Front building has left him without access to his apartment for nearly a week so far. The fire was the result of faulty wiring within a wall on the floor above his unit. The Iron Front offered some of the last affordable housing here in town and with no indication of units reopening up for occupancy Juno is looking for another apartment in a very tight rental market. He is currently relying on friends and couch surfing for lodging. As Juno is only recently an adult with fairly low wages we do our best to provide financial support already for his semi-independent living but this latest financial fallout is tough for our family to provide Juno with all he needs.
We hope you will be able to join us in supporting Juno after this unexpected transition, and with the increase in rent he will experience in the coming months. Your support will go to a fund that will be used to supplement Juno's monthly rental payment and will be administered by my wife and me. 
Thank you! 
Adam

🍯🌎❤️🌍🍯 Yesterday morning I was working away carving porcelain pots in my studio when I heard a knock at the door. It’s important to know that knocks at my porcelain studio door are a rare occurrence, the studio is outside of town and most visitors come to the main entrance and schedule visits ahead of time. I motioned to my visitor to open the door and come in thinking it was likely one of our Airbnb guests looking for the washer/dryer. The gentleman who entered greeted me in heavily Northern European accented English, introduced himself as Nils, and explained that he was a documentary film maker from Norway who happened to be in the area working on a film. Nils ex-wife is a longtime potter who had studied Onggi in Korea on a number of occasions and when she heard that he was going to be in Helena she sent him my way. This unexpected visit from a kind visitor from afar has me reflecting on how grateful I am to be in a profession that allows such random connections to happen. Great to meet Nils and to hear about his projects and his homeland. Happy to know that my work will be well used and appreciated in its new Norwegian home on a small island about 2 hours south of Oslo. 
❤️

🍶🔥🍶💥🍶 My studio assistant Frank (@flanzante) mixed up a batch of pottery plaster to add to the existing porcelain reclaim rack. The new plaster should help to speed up the drying process for reconstituted porcelain scraps. It always feels so good to put work into making the studio more efficient. Thanks Frank!
🔥🍶🔥 So thrilled to be holding these amazing pieces by Ali Schieman (@ali_schorman) after admiring them through the screen!

❄️🍶🔄👌🏼❄️ I’ve always enjoyed making a lid with a snug fit and a smooth connection but after some good conversations at the Montana Clay Tour with Cooper Jeppesen (@hearth.tea.and.table) and Chris Alveshere (@chriscookskilns) I’ve been inspired to up my lid fit game. I make my lids just a bit too large and fire them as such. After unloading I grind the lid to fit using silicon carbide dust made into a paste, it’s like liquid sandpaper. It not only makes for a tight fitting lid but the smooth slide between lid and jar is so nice!! Volume up and enjoy.

🔥🍯💪🏼🔥 I am fortunate to have had many great teachers in clay and beyond and among them my Onggi teacher Kim Young Ho has made an immeasurable impact on the pots I make, how I think about the act of making pots, and the greater societal value I place upon making pots by hand. I am so grateful that his son Kim Heegun is not only carrying on the Kim family Onggi tradition but is also documenting the journey here on Instagram (@heegunonggi). I ow so much to the Kim family and with that debt I feel responsible to share as much information as possible related to an accurate portrayal of the tradition that they carry and that I was lucky enough to have been trusted to carry to a new audience beyond their reach. Sending sincere gratitude to Ohbuja Onggi and the Kim family for welcoming me into your studio and home and for trusting me with this ancient knowledge. 
•
Original post by @heegunonggi 
•
Original caption by Kim Heegun:
“The master of Korean ceramics - Kim Yong-ho
My father has more than 20 years of experience making pottery. father always tell me that a small jar is the most difficult. The reason is that the process of attaching the handle and it is difficult to hold the center of the jar. I edit and share the video of my father making Onggi. Please enjoy the show 🎥🙏”

💥🍺💥 Letting off some pressure on Jesse’s (@wildwillowwellness) first batch of Nanking cherry mugwort (both locally grown and harvested!) beer based on a recipe from @pascalbaudar wonderful book, The Wildcrafting Brewer! Like all things in life there’s a bit of a learning curve. After a few attempts to open some bottles that resulted in covering most of the mudroom and kitchen in beer we switched to gradually easing off the over-pressurized bottles over about 30 minutes. With a large gathering this weekend we needed to come up with a faster way to let off the pressure and this method ended up working well! Next time we will check the bottles more regularly to avoid so much pressure build up. The beer is delicious!

😂🍶😆 When mom says we have pottery at home.

💥🍶💥🍯💥 QUALITY CONTROL! Dealing with a few process and material related flawed pots today. The porcelain bowls were thrown off the hump and left a touch thick and the carving lines were the final straw and resulted in some cracked bases. With the Onggi lids we somehow got a bit of plaster into the reclaim which made for some blowouts. I’m not a fan of putting my seconds out into that world and much prefer destroying the evidence 😂. Where do you draw the line between sellable work and garbage?

💙🍶💙 With single digit temps in our forecast we took advantage of a beautiful day yesterday to take back a big part of the porcelain studio. Frank (@flanzante) and I gathering up all of my all of my porcelain trimmings and dumped them in a 55-gallon drum for cold storage and easy access when it comes time to recycle the clay. After some YouTube research I was happy to learn that a carefully cut barrel top works as a tight fitting lid when flipped over, who knew?! The dry porcelain scraps will get mixed with water in a 5-gallon bucket before being laid out to dry to a workable consistency on my large plaster recycling table.

💙🍶💙 Carving a lid is the last step of the wet work stage of my carved porcelain jars and always carries a sense of relief upon completion. I often make two lids for each jar to be sure I have a lid that fits right after glaze firing. I’ve been playing with some pattern on the top of the knob and on the interior of each lid using a serrated rib moved in just the right way as a last step to throwing.
❤️🍶❤️ Trimming Dimple cups on this cool and rainy fall afternoon with the fire warming my back. 😌

🇰🇷🍯💪🏼 During my 2008 Onggi apprenticeship the person I spent the most time with in the studio was Kim Young-Ho. Observing his unbelievable work ethic and meticulous attention to the smallest detail of each and every piece he made. Kim Young-Ho worked steadily with a seemingly tireless stamina made all the more impressive given the physically demanding nature of the Onggi making process. In my year with the Kim family I worked harder than I had up to that point in my life. I feel fortunate to have been welcomed into this ancient tradition and to have shared most of that time with such an amazing craftsman. 
•
Kim Young-Ho’s son, Kim Heegun (@heegunonggi) is carrying on the family Onggi tradition and is sharing the studio experience with a wider audience here on Instagram. Please head over to his feed and tap follow for a rare glimpse into one of the last remaining authentic Onggi studios in Korea.
•

💪🏼🍯💪🏼🍯💪🏼 Imagine the skill it takes to make  just one of these large onggi jars now imagine Kim Young-Ho making SIX of them each day for two weeks. That is how a kiln load of onggi gets started (that’s right, largest pots are made first to allow them to completely dry before firing) at Ohbuja Onggi (@heegunonggi). When I arrived at Ohbuja Onggi as an apprentice in 2008 I was completely unprepared for the volume, consistency, and speed of production. It was truly unbelievable. I am so grateful for the view into the Ohbuja studio provided by Kim Heegun (Kim Young-Ho’s son) through his Instagram posts.

💞🍶💞 I’ve had a lot of requests for a how-to video after posting a smooth spinning lid a little while back. I learned this from @connellypottery and @alleghanymeadows while attending their co-taught workshop at @archie_bray back in 2004. If my memory serves they had learned this from Val Cushing as grad students at Alfred. It’s a great way to achieve a smooth, soft, and snug fit for your lids. 
I plan ahead a bit by making my lids just about 1 mm too big for the pot so that the lid doesn’t actually fit when the piece comes out of the kiln. My lids are fired in place on top of the jar so I end up using a small coil of wadding as a gasket between the jar and the lid, this helps to keep the glaze results consistent between the two pieces and also helps to keep the rim of the jar from warping out of round. I was originally taught to use water based (not oil based) valve grinding compound which can be purchased at most auto parts stores in a little tube (like toothpaste). At some point I switched to buying fine silicon carbide dust from the ceramic supplier and just mixing it with water to form a paste as you see in this video. A not about water vs oil based, the water based compound is much easier to clean up and doesn’t require soap to break the grease up. Depending on the size of the jar and lid you can either hold both in your hands for it for bigger pieces I find it helpful to use the wheel. The total time it took me to grind this lid smooth was about 15 minutes. I know the sound is annoying but listen closely and you’ll hear the gradual smoothing of the contact between the two pieces and finally a smooth glassy glide with a nearly airtight fit. It’s a small detail but in the end the small details make all the difference! 
•

🎁🍶🎁 I have been hosting Studio Shadow Sessions here in my Helena, Montana studio for nearly three years now. As the world navigated uncertain times during the pandemic, my passion for teaching pottery found new wings! Unable to travel to teach workshops, I transformed the challenge into an opportunity: introducing tailored 5-day and 7-day Studio Shadow Sessions right here in my own studio. It’s been a joy to offer this personalized, immersive experience, crafting a space for potters to explore their passion one-on-one, regardless of their skill level or stage in the clay journey.

And what better time to gift this experience than the holiday season? Consider the gift of creativity, nature, and pottery—a Christmas treat for your loved ones or yourself! Participants not only dive into the world of ceramics but also enjoy the picturesque surroundings, staying in the cozy artist loft apartment above the studio. Nestled amidst the captivating foothills and hiking trails, my studio offers more than a creative space—it’s an immersion into nature’s inspiration. Plus, a visit to the globally renowned Archie Bray Foundation (just a stone’s throw away!)adds an extra sparkle to this unique artistic expedition.

Join me in embracing creativity and gifting the joy of pottery, nature, and exploration this holiday season! 

Message me for full details and availability. 

✨🏺🎄🎁🌿✨

🪚🪵🛠️ An end of year project has me switching from clay to wood for this Christmas gift build for my daughters to display their vinyl record collections! I am not a great woodworker so I laid some ground rules for myself as I got started. Rule # 1 Patience! I find myself wanting to work at a faster pace which I’ve grown accustomed to from working with clay. When working with a less familiar material tools I find it helpful to actively and repeatedly tell myself to slow down and it makes for a far more enjoyable experience and a better end product. I had some help in the form of a YouTube clip from @hoborec as well as some big support from Devon 👶🏻 and Tikkuna 🐺! I finished the project in time for Christmas and with a short list of things I would do better next time. 
•
Wishing you and your family a happy holiday season as we welcome longer and brighter days back into our lives!

❤️🍶❤️ Making sectional pots is always an emotional rollercoaster ride. The intimidation ahead of getting started, the big boost of excitement when the sections are attached doubling the size of the piece, and the joy of bringing the form into completion. Next this piece will get a lid and a decorative raised coil attached at the seam before I get to work carving a new favorite pattern onto the exterior of this jar.

🌸🍶🌸 PART 2: After some requests for a follow up video for this sectional covered jar here is the next step. Using blue food coloring (it burns out without a trace) to keep track of the seam between the two sections I am adding an extruded coil to fortify and accentuate the joint. Jumping into carving this big boy today. Stay tuned!

Family, travel, pottery, and all other things that twist my brain in a good way ✨🌟✨
